articles.headline: Seeking Investment Flexibility In a 401(k)
articles.snippet: Most employees in 401(k) plans dutifully accept the menu of mutual funds chosen by their employers. But adding a self-directed option could improve plans.
articles.abstract: Most employees in 401(k) plans dutifully accept the menu of mutual funds chosen by their employers. But adding a self-directed option could improve plans.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a perfect world, we could buy whatever investments we wanted for our 401(k) or similar workplace retirement account.

articles.headline: Air Service Cutbacks Hit Hardest Where Recession Did
articles.snippet: Government data shows that cities where house prices collapsed and jobs disappeared, like Las Vegas and Detroit, were among those that lost the most flights.
articles.abstract: Government data shows that cities where house prices collapsed and jobs disappeared, like Las Vegas and Detroit, were among those that lost the most flights.
articles.lead_paragraph: The airlines’ deep cutbacks in flights over the last three years have fallen unevenly across the country, largely sparing the nation’s biggest airports but hitting midsize airports the hardest.

articles.headline: Waiting for Gravity to Hit LinkedIn
articles.snippet: Spotting a bubble before it deflates has proved difficult, if not impossible, but that hasn’t stopped questions about LinkedIn’s stock price.
articles.abstract: Spotting a bubble before it deflates has proved difficult, if not impossible, but that hasn’t stopped questions about LinkedIn’s stock price.
articles.lead_paragraph: Facebook’s valuation in the private market this week was approaching $100 billion. Twitter is in the midst of a round of private fund-raising on terms that value it at as much as $8 billion — more than double its worth a mere seven months ago. The Internet coupon distributor Groupon filed in June for a public offering that could raise $30 billion, and the online game networker Zynga followed this week with a potential $20 billion offering.

articles.headline: Allegations Link U.S. Companies to Brazilian Sex Tourism
articles.snippet: Cases in the United States and Brazil are pursuing connections between an Atlanta-area businessman and trafficking in underage girls along the Amazon, according to court papers.
articles.abstract: Cases in the United States and Brazil are pursuing connections between an Atlanta-area businessman and trafficking in underage girls along the Amazon, according to court papers.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Justice Department has been conducting a criminal investigation of sports fishing expeditions in the Amazon that may have been used as covers for Americans to have sex with underage girls, according to newly filed court papers.

articles.headline: As Same-Sex Marriage Becomes Legal, Some Choices May Be Lost
articles.snippet: Companies like Corning, I.B.M. and Raytheon are requiring employees to marry if they want their same-sex partners to qualify for health insurance.
articles.abstract: Companies like Corning, I.B.M. and Raytheon are requiring employees to marry if they want their same-sex partners to qualify for health insurance.
articles.lead_paragraph: Now that same-sex marriage has been legalized in New York, at least a few large companies are requiring their employees to tie the knot if they want their partners to qualify for health insurance.

articles.headline: Phone Scandal Poses Defining Test for a Murdoch Son
articles.snippet: James Murdoch, the son of Rupert Murdoch, faces a new test as he jockeys to run his father’s company, the News Corporation, and salvage the biggest deal in the Murdochs’ history.
articles.abstract: James Murdoch, the son of Rupert Murdoch, faces a new test as he jockeys to run his father’s company, the News Corporation, and salvage the biggest deal in the Murdochs’ history.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Thursday afternoon, James Murdoch assembled senior executives in the top-floor boardroom in the News Corporation’s London headquarters and told them of a momentous decision: to shutter the 168-year-old tabloid at the center of a deepening phone-hacking scandal and the original heart of the Murdoch media empire in Britain.

articles.headline: Betty Ford, Former First Lady, Dies at 93
articles.snippet: The much-admired wife of President Gerald R. Ford overcame addiction and helped found one of the most well-known rehabilitation centers in the U.S.
articles.abstract: The much-admired wife of President Gerald R. Ford overcame addiction and helped found one of the most well-known rehabilitation centers in the U.S.
articles.lead_paragraph: Betty Ford, the outspoken and much-admired wife of President Gerald R. Ford who overcame alcoholism and an addiction to pills and helped found one of the best-known rehabilitation centers in the nation, died Friday in Rancho Mirage, Calif. She was 93.

articles.headline: Night Raids Curbing Taliban, but Afghans Cite Civilian Toll
articles.snippet: Night raids have become an effective tool against the insurgents even as they stir resentment and accusations of abuse among Afghans.
articles.abstract: Night raids have become an effective tool against the insurgents even as they stir resentment and accusations of abuse among Afghans.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — United States Special Operations forces have carried out an extraordinary number of night raids over the past year, turning them into one of their most effective tools against the insurgents even as they stir accusations of abuse, resentment among Afghans and divisions with the government.

articles.headline: Trailing G.O.P. With Cameras, Seeking Gaffes
articles.snippet: A group is looking for gotcha moments that could derail political ambitions or provide fodder for TV ads.
articles.abstract: A group is looking for gotcha moments that could derail political ambitions or provide fodder for TV ads.
articles.lead_paragraph: AMHERST, N.H. — Aaron Fielding quietly stalks his prey — Republicans — with his video camera, patiently waiting for a political moment worthy of YouTube.

articles.headline: When S’Mores Aren’t Enough: The New Economics of Summer Camp
articles.snippet: The economy has made the business of summer camp tougher — so having fun is only part of the equation. Many camps now offer special services to please demanding families.
articles.abstract: The economy has made the business of summer camp tougher — so having fun is only part of the equation. Many camps now offer special services to please demanding families.
articles.lead_paragraph: Greeley, Pa.

articles.headline: For Years, the Tabloids’ Sting Kept British Politicians in Line
articles.snippet: Fear of media harassment and political necessity have long underpinned the uneasy collusion between British politicians and the nation’s tabloids.
articles.abstract: Fear of media harassment and political necessity have long underpinned the uneasy collusion between British politicians and the nation’s tabloids.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — In 2004, Clare Short, a Labour member of Parliament, learned what could happen to British politicians who criticized the country’s unforgiving tabloids. At a lunch in Westminster, Ms. Short mentioned in passing that she did not care for the photographs of saucy, topless women that appear every day on Page 3 of the populist tabloid The Sun, owned by Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation. “I’d like to take the pornography out of our press,” she said.

articles.headline: Somehow, the Unemployed Became Invisible
articles.snippet: In past downturns, Americans demanded politicians’ attention. But this time, the nation’s jobless are mostly just enduring.
articles.abstract: In past downturns, Americans demanded politicians’ attention. But this time, the nation’s jobless are mostly just enduring.
articles.lead_paragraph: GRIM number of the week: 14,087,000.

articles.headline: Tough Calculus as Technical Schools Face Deep Cuts
articles.snippet: Federal funding is at risk for vocational and technical courses that may keep disengaged students in school.
articles.abstract: Federal funding is at risk for vocational and technical courses that may keep disengaged students in school.
articles.lead_paragraph: GREENSBORO, N.C. — Despite a competitive economy in which success increasingly depends on obtaining a college degree, one in four students in this country does not even finish high school in the usual four years.

articles.headline: U.S. Is Deferring Millions in Pakistani Military Aid
articles.snippet: The cancellation of hundreds of millions in aid is meant to chasten Pakistan for expelling American trainers and press its army to fight militants more effectively.
articles.abstract: The cancellation of hundreds of millions in aid is meant to chasten Pakistan for expelling American trainers and press its army to fight militants more effectively.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration is suspending and, in some cases, canceling hundreds of millions of dollars of aid to the Pakistani military, in a move to chasten Pakistan for expelling American military trainers and to press its army to fight militants more effectively.
articles.byline: By Eric Schmitt and Jane Perlez

articles.headline: Wichita Doctor Takes Up Fight for Abortions
articles.snippet: In a city where the last abortion provider was fatally shot two years ago, a potential replacement has emerged but faces her own challenges.
articles.abstract: In a city where the last abortion provider was fatally shot two years ago, a potential replacement has emerged but faces her own challenges.
articles.lead_paragraph: WICHITA, Kan. — Not long ago, Dr. Mila Means, the physician trying to open an abortion clinic in this city, received a letter advising her to check under her car each morning — “because maybe today is the day someone places an explosive under it,” the note said.

articles.headline: Obama Leans on G.O.P. for a Deal on Debt Ceiling
articles.snippet: President Obama met with Congressional leaders to try to revive chances for a $4 trillion deal to avert a default on the national debt, a day after Speaker John A. Boehner appeared to dash hopes for any far-reaching agreement.
articles.abstract: President Obama met with Congressional leaders to try to revive chances for a $4 trillion deal to avert a default on the national debt, a day after Speaker John A. Boehner appeared to dash hopes for any far-reaching agreement.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama tried on Sunday to revive the chances for a sweeping budget agreement to reduce the nation’s deficit and repair its perilous finances, but Congressional Republicans continued to balk, insisting on a more modest deal to avert a default on the national debt.

articles.headline: Italian Debt Adds to Fears in Euro Zone
articles.snippet: Top European officials were to meet Monday as fears grew that Italy could become the latest victim of the debt crisis.
articles.abstract: Top European officials were to meet Monday as fears grew that Italy could become the latest victim of the debt crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Top European officials planned to meet on Monday to wrestle with threats to the currency union as fears mounted that Italy could become a victim of the debt crisis even as discussions stalled over a second bailout for Greece.

articles.headline: A Compass for Conservative Politics
articles.snippet: Newsmax has become a potent force by offering what its chief executive calls “news that Americans in the heartland would like to see.”
articles.abstract: Newsmax has become a potent force by offering what its chief executive calls “news that Americans in the heartland would like to see.”
articles.lead_paragraph: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla. — Without the soupy South Florida humidity and the fastidiously clipped lawn, the Newsmax headquarters here would be a lot like one of those diners in New Hampshire and Iowa where autographed pictures of politicians cover the walls.

articles.headline: Wall St. Banks Expected to Post Weak 2nd-Quarter Results
articles.snippet: After a sizzling first quarter, the weakening economy and an array of worrisome global events have Wall Street planning for big revenue drops and new rounds of layoffs.
articles.abstract: After a sizzling first quarter, the weakening economy and an array of worrisome global events have Wall Street planning for big revenue drops and new rounds of layoffs.
articles.lead_paragraph: Only a few short months ago, JPMorgan Chase traders were on such a roll that they did not have a single losing day in the first quarter.

articles.headline: Despite Violence, U.S. Firms Expand in Mexico
articles.snippet: American manufacturers in Mexico are expanding along the border, a stark paradox during violent times there.
articles.abstract: American manufacturers in Mexico are expanding along the border, a stark paradox during violent times there.
articles.lead_paragraph: MATAMOROS, Mexico — When the latest bloody headlines from the drug war in Mexico reach headquarters in New York, Ken Chandler, the manager of an American electronics manufacturing plant here, jumps on the phone.

articles.headline: Music Site Lets Users Play D.J. to Virtual, and Discerning, Crowds
articles.snippet: Turntable.fm and other new sites try to recreate the feeling of being with friends at a concert when listening to music at home.
articles.abstract: Turntable.fm and other new sites try to recreate the feeling of being with friends at a concert when listening to music at home.
articles.lead_paragraph: The hottest new club isn’t in Los Angeles or New York. It’s on a Web site called Turntable.fm, where big-headed cartoon characters populate the D.J. booth.

articles.headline: A Tabloid Shame, Exposed by Earnest Rivals
articles.snippet: For Rupert Murdoch, newspapers have been useful in wielding influence and are the very thing that brought his company into the cross hairs.
articles.abstract: For Rupert Murdoch, newspapers have been useful in wielding influence and are the very thing that brought his company into the cross hairs.
articles.lead_paragraph: The phone-hacking scandal that is mushrooming in Britain, with arrests, skullduggery and influence peddling, would be a delicious story for The News of the World if it were not about the newspaper itself. Instead, the hunter became the hunted, and last Thursday Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation summarily slid the 168-year-old News of the World under a double-decker bus. Its final issue was Sunday.

articles.headline: For Boehner, Lofty Budget Goals Checked by Reality
articles.snippet: Speaker John A. Boehner’s ambitions for a budget deal quickly crashed into a divided, highly partisan Congress.
articles.abstract: Speaker John A. Boehner’s ambitions for a budget deal quickly crashed into a divided, highly partisan Congress.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — At a private meeting about deficit reduction at the White House last week, Speaker John A. Boehner told his fellow Congressional leaders and President Obama that he did not spend 20 years working his way up to the top job on Capitol Hill just for the cachet of the title — he wanted to accomplish something big.

articles.headline: Quick Action Helps Google Win Friends in Japan
articles.snippet: Through efforts like a Person Finder site and Street View recordings after the earthquake and tsunami, Google is finally winning over new friends in Japan.
articles.abstract: Through efforts like a Person Finder site and Street View recordings after the earthquake and tsunami, Google is finally winning over new friends in Japan.
articles.lead_paragraph: KESENNUMA, Japan — An oddly equipped car made its way last week through the rubble in this tsunami-stricken port city. On the roof: an assembly of nine cameras creating 360-degree panoramic digital images of the disaster zone to archive damage.

articles.headline: Economy Faces a Jolt as Benefit Checks Run Out
articles.snippet: About 20 percent of personal income comes from government payments, and as programs are trimmed, reduced consumer spending could slow the recovery.
articles.abstract: About 20 percent of personal income comes from government payments, and as programs are trimmed, reduced consumer spending could slow the recovery.
articles.lead_paragraph: An extraordinary amount of personal income is coming directly from the government.

articles.headline: In Europe, an Outline of Options
articles.snippet: European finance ministers promised on Monday to lighten lending terms for struggling countries like Greece and suggested that the existing bailout fund be expanded.
articles.abstract: European finance ministers promised on Monday to lighten lending terms for struggling countries like Greece and suggested that the existing bailout fund be expanded.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — European finance ministers promised on Monday to lighten lending terms for struggling countries like Greece and suggested that the existing bailout fund be expanded and allowed to pay for the purchase of sovereign bonds.
articles.byline: By Stephen Castle and Jack Ewing
